topic_name: Adolescent Nutrition-Clinical and Programmatic Perspectives in India

subtopics.subtopic_title: Criteria for nutritional assessment and anthropometric measurements in adolescents
subtopics.concept: Nutritional assessment and anthropometric measurements in adolescents are critical components of paediatric care, particularly in the Indian context where malnutrition and micronutrient deficiencies are prevalent. Clinical assessment remains the cornerstone, complemented by laboratory investigations when indicated. Routine laboratory screening is not necessary for all adolescents, especially when nutritional status is only mildly compromised. However, annual anemia screening is mandated for all adolescents under programs like Anemia Mukt Bharat, as approximately 50% of adolescent girls aged 15–19 years are anemic. Hemoglobin levels should be checked annually, and if not done, a point-of-care hemoglobin test is advised. The World Health Organization (WHO) defines anemia in adolescents as hemoglobin <12 g/dL for 12–14-year-olds and females aged ≥15 years, and <13 g/dL for males aged ≥15 years. Severity is classified as mild (10–11.9 g/dL in nonpregnant girls), moderate (8–10.9 g/dL), and severe (<8 g/dL). Low hemoglobin necessitates further evaluation, including serum ferritin levels to confirm iron deficiency, the most common cause of adolescent anemia. Ferritin <15 mg/L in adults and <12 mg/L in children confirms iron deficiency, although some clinicians use thresholds of <30 mg/L for higher sensitivity or <100 mg/L in the presence of inflammation. Additional iron studies, such as transferrin saturation (<16–20%), may support the diagnosis. Anthropometric tools are essential for quantifying nutritional status. Body mass index (BMI)-for-age is a primary indicator, with <5th percentile confirming underweight and >95th percentile confirming obesity. Growth charts, particularly WHO/IAP standards, are invaluable for tracking height and weight over time, allowing early detection of stunting, thinness, or obesity before clinical symptoms arise. Skinfold thickness and mid-upper arm circumference can assess body fat and muscle mass but are less commonly used in routine practice. Dietary assessments, including a 3-day diet record analyzed by a dietitian or mobile apps, can estimate daily intake of calories, protein, and micronutrients, highlighting deficiencies such as iron intake below the recommended ~15 mg/day for adolescent girls. Early identification of nutritional issues through systematic evaluation enables timely intervention to optimize adolescent growth and health.

case_studies.title: Nutritional Concerns in a 14-Year-Old Girl with Fatigue
case_studies.vignette: A 14-year-old girl from a rural Indian village presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of persistent fatigue and decreased concentration in school over the past three months. Her mother reports that she has been eating less and prefers rice over vegetables and pulses. The family has limited access to diverse food options due to financial constraints. On examination, she appears pale and has a BMI-for-age in the 3rd percentile. Her height and weight have not increased significantly since her last visit six months ago. A point-of-care hemoglobin test reveals a level of 9.2 g/dL.
case_studies.learning_objective: Understand criteria for nutritional assessment and interpret anthropometric and hemoglobin findings in adolescents.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Standardized tools and interpretation of BMI-for-age and weight-for-height charts for adolescents
subtopics.concept: Anthropometric measurements are fundamental in assessing nutritional status during adolescence, a period marked by significant growth and pubertal changes. For adolescents aged approximately 10–19 years, key measurements include weight, height, and circumferences (in specific contexts), which are used to calculate indices such as BMI-for-age. Accurate measurement techniques are crucial to avoid errors in interpretation: weight should be measured using a calibrated scale with minimal clothing, while height should be measured with a wall-mounted stadiometer or measuring tape, ensuring the adolescent stands barefoot with heels, buttocks, and shoulders touching the vertical surface. Interpretation of these measurements requires age- and sex-specific reference data due to the variability introduced by pubertal growth spurts and sex-related differences. Clinicians rely on growth charts to interpret anthropometric data. For adolescents aged 5–18 years in India, the Indian Academy of Pediatrics (IAP) recommends the 2015 revised IAP growth charts, which are tailored to Indian ethnic growth patterns and include distinct BMI cut-offs for overweight and obesity. These charts differ slightly from the World Health Organization (WHO) growth reference standards for ages 5–19 years, which are based on a multi-ethnic dataset. When plotting measurements, it is essential to use the correct age- and sex-specific chart. BMI-for-age charts are preferred for adolescents over 10 years, as weight-for-age charts are only valid up to 10 years and do not account for height-related weight changes during puberty. BMI-for-age below the 3rd or 5th percentile indicates underweight (thinness), while values above the 85th percentile indicate overweight, and above the 95th percentile indicate obesity, according to CDC or IAP criteria. WHO uses Z-score thresholds analogously: BMI < –2 SD indicates thinness, < –3 SD severe thinness, > +1 SD overweight (equivalent to adult BMI of 25 at 19 years), and > +2 SD obesity (BMI of 30 at 19 years). The IAP guidelines propose alternate cut-offs for Indian adolescents, defining overweight at BMI corresponding to adult BMI 23 kg/m² (~BMI-for-age Z > +0.8 SD) and obesity at 27 kg/m² (~BMI-for-age Z > +1.5 SD), reflecting the higher metabolic risk at lower BMI in South Asian populations. In practice, Indian pediatricians often plot BMI and consider both percentiles and these specific cut-offs. Height-for-age charts are used to assess stunting or tall stature. A height below the 3rd percentile (approximately –2 SD) for age and sex indicates stunting, often due to chronic undernutrition or long-standing factors. Genetic potential, assessed via mid-parental height, provides a target range for expected adult height. A significant deviation from this range may suggest nutritional stunting or systemic issues. Height velocity increases during puberty, with peak height velocity occurring at approximately 11–13 years in girls and 13–15 years in boys. A single height measurement must be interpreted in the context of pubertal timing; for instance, a late-blooming 14-year-old boy may appear short for age but could catch up later. Serial height measurements taken 6–12 months apart are more reliable for identifying growth faltering, as crossing percentiles downward indicates stunting or growth issues.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Screening protocols and management guidelines for micronutrient deficiencies in Indian adolescents (Iron, Vitamin D, Iodine)
subtopics.concept: Micronutrient deficiencies, particularly involving iron, vitamin D, and iodine, are prevalent among Indian adolescents and require targeted screening and management protocols. Adolescents, especially girls, are at heightened risk due to the physiological demands of puberty and the onset of menstruation, which exacerbate iron loss. National data indicate that anemia affects approximately 40% of female adolescents compared to 18% of males, while iron deficiency (defined by low serum ferritin) impacts 31% of girls versus 12% of boys. Vitamin D deficiency also increases with age, with one in four teenagers exhibiting low 25(OH)D levels, likely due to lifestyle factors such as limited sun exposure and increased nutritional requirements. Socio-cultural factors further compound these risks, as adolescent girls in certain communities may receive less nutritious food, increasing their susceptibility to anemia and vitamin D deficiency. For effective screening, hemoglobin (Hb) measurement is the primary test for anemia, with thresholds defined by the WHO: Hb <12 g/dL for both sexes aged 12–14 years, Hb <12 g/dL for girls aged ≥15 years, and Hb <13 g/dL for boys aged ≥15 years. Once anemia is confirmed, serum ferritin is the diagnostic marker for iron deficiency, with values <15 mg/L being highly specific for depleted iron stores in adolescents. However, ferritin is an acute-phase reactant and may be elevated in the presence of inflammation, necessitating the use of higher thresholds, such as <30 mg/L or <100 mg/L, when C-reactive protein (CRP) or erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) is elevated. Complementary iron studies, including low serum iron, transferrin saturation (Tsat) <16–20%, and elevated total iron-binding capacity (TIBC), further support the diagnosis of iron deficiency anemia (IDA). Soluble transferrin receptor levels, unaffected by inflammation, can also confirm iron deficiency but are less commonly available. Pediatricians should implement systematic screening protocols tailored to the specific vulnerabilities of adolescents, with particular emphasis on addressing iron deficiency in girls through interventions such as school-based weekly iron-folic acid supplementation. Early detection and management are essential to break the intergenerational cycle of malnutrition and improve adolescent health outcomes.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Identifying and addressing cultural barriers to healthy eating in India
subtopics.concept: Identifying and addressing cultural barriers to healthy eating in India is crucial for promoting optimal paediatric nutrition, particularly among adolescents. Non-pharmacological interventions form the cornerstone of management, focusing on dietary counseling and modification tailored to individual needs. For undernourished adolescents, the goal is to increase calorie and protein intake in a culturally acceptable and affordable manner. Practical strategies include adding calorie-dense snacks like peanut butter sandwiches or nuts with bananas between meals and enriching traditional dishes with ghee, oil, milk powder, or nut paste. Protein intake should be emphasized, with a target of at least 1 gram per kilogram of body weight daily. For instance, a 40 kg underweight girl should aim for approximately 40 grams of protein from sources like pulses, legumes, eggs, milk, and, if non-vegetarian, meat or fish. Small, frequent meals and establishing a routine to avoid skipping meals can help adolescents with low appetite. For overweight adolescents, dietary modifications should focus on reducing high-sugar and high-fat foods without resorting to restrictive or fad diets, as these can negatively impact growth. Practical advice includes limiting sugary drinks, such as reducing consumption of colas from two per day to none or a maximum of one per week, and replacing them with water, coconut water, or unsweetened lemonade. Fast food intake can be reduced from three times a week to once weekly, with healthier homemade alternatives encouraged. Adolescents should be taught to read food labels to understand calorie, sugar, and fat content, empowering them to make informed choices. The concept of "juncs" foods (junk, ultra-processed, nutritionally inappropriate, caffeinated drinks, and sugar-sweetened beverages) is emphasized, with energy drinks and sodas discouraged per AAP and IAP guidelines. Instead, traditional drinks like buttermilk, milk, and water are recommended. Physical activity is integral to both under- and overweight adolescents. Strength training can stimulate muscle growth and appetite in underweight teens, while a combination of aerobic and strength exercises aids fat loss and metabolic health in overweight teens. Fun activities like dance, sports, or games should be encouraged to ensure sustainability. Screen time should be limited to less than two hours per day to reduce sedentary behavior and prevent mindless snacking. Families can promote active outings and avoid using food as the sole reward for achievements. Addressing body image concerns is essential, especially for girls influenced by unrealistic media portrayals. Building self-esteem and focusing on non-appearance-related strengths can mitigate unhealthy eating behaviors, such as self-induced vomiting, laxative use, or starvation.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Management strategies for unhealthy dietary behaviors in Indian adolescents
subtopics.concept: Management strategies for unhealthy dietary behaviors in Indian adolescents emphasize non-pharmacological interventions, which are foundational at both individual and community levels. Dietary counseling and modification are central to addressing nutritional concerns. For undernourished adolescents, the focus is on increasing calorie and protein intake in a palatable and affordable manner. Practical recommendations include adding calorie-dense snacks, such as a peanut butter sandwich or a handful of nuts and a banana, between meals. Enhancing main meals with a spoon of ghee or oil in dals and rice or enriching porridge with milk powder or nut paste is encouraged. Protein intake should be tailored to at least 1 gram per kilogram of body weight daily, sourced from pulses, legumes, eggs, milk, and meat or fish (if non-vegetarian). For example, a 40 kg underweight girl should aim for approximately 40 grams of protein daily. Small, frequent meals are helpful for adolescents with low appetite, and maintaining a regular eating schedule without skipping meals is essential. For overweight adolescents, the dietary strategy revolves around moderation and healthy substitutions rather than restrictive or fad diets, which can adversely affect growth. Adolescents should reduce high-sugar and high-fat items, such as sugary colas or frequent fast food, replacing them with healthier alternatives like water, coconut water, unsweetened lemonade, or homemade snacks. Teaching adolescents to read food labels for calorie, sugar, and fat content is empowering, as it helps them make informed choices. The concept of "juncs" foods—junk food, ultra-processed items, sugar-sweetened beverages, and caffeinated drinks—is actively discouraged, with guidelines from AAP and IAP stating that stimulant-containing energy drinks should be avoided entirely. Instead, traditional drinks like buttermilk, milk, and water are recommended. Visual tools like the "plate method," which divides the plate into half vegetables, a quarter protein, and a quarter grains, can help adolescents balance portions effectively. Strength training under proper guidance can stimulate muscle growth and appetite in thin adolescents, while a mix of aerobic and strength exercises aids fat loss and metabolic health in overweight teens. Fun, sustainable activities like dance, sports, or games are encouraged, alongside limiting recreational screen time to less than two hours daily to reduce sedentary behavior and mindless snacking. Families should promote active outings and avoid using food as the sole reward for achievements. Addressing body image concerns is critical, particularly for adolescents influenced by unrealistic media portrayals. Discussions on healthy ways to achieve fitness, building self-esteem, and focusing on non-appearance-related strengths can mitigate unhealthy dietary behaviors. Extreme measures like self-induced vomiting, laxative use, or starvation require urgent attention.

PERSPECTIVES

EATING DISORDERS (EDs) IN ADOLESCENTS – principally anorexia nervosa (AN), bulimia nervosa
(BN),  AND binge-EATING disorder (BED) – require early identification AND a multidisciplinary
MANAGEMENT strategy. Pediatricians play a key role IN SCREENING FOR EDs during routine visits
AND providing initial MANAGEMENT focused on NUTRITIONAL rehabilitation AND medical stability,
while coordinating with mental health professionals FOR psychotherapy. From a CLINICAL
perspective, EATING DISORDERS lie at the intersection OF NUTRITION AND mental health, so AN
integrated APPROACH is essential.  SCREENING AND Early Recognition: ADOLESCENTS with EATING
DISORDERS often conceal their  symptoms, so clinicians must maintain a high index OF suspicion.
Routine SCREENING questions  about BODY IMAGE AND EATING behaviors should be part OF ADOLESCENT
health visits. Red flags  include dramatic weight loss or fluctuation, intense fear OF weight
gain, a distorted BODY IMAGE  (e.g. a teen WHO is underweight but perceives themselves as
“fat”), or unusual EATING habits  (skipping meals, hyper-focusing on calories, secret binge
EATING). Physical signs can be subtle early  on – fatigue, dizziness, cold intolerance,
menstrual irregularities IN girls (amenorrhea is common IN  anorexia due to low BODY fat), or
unexplained gastrointestinal complaints. One practical SCREENING  tool is the SCOFF
questionnaire (five yes/no questions about EATING attitudes); although originally  validated IN
Western settings, it can be used IN India to quickly gauge risk, with ‡2 “yes” answers
suggesting possible ED (it asks about feeling out OF Control over EATING, lost >6 kg rapidly,
vomiting  to control weight, seeing oneself as Fat, AND Food dominating life). The American
Academy OF  Pediatrics recommends that any ADOLESCENT with weight <5th percentile or unexpected
weight  drop OF >10% be evaluated FOR disordered EATING, among other causes. IN overweight
teens,  warning signs OF bulimia or BED include weight cycling, parotid gland swelling, dental

subtopics.subtopic_title: Obesity risk stratification, early intervention protocols, and lifestyle modification counselling for adolescents
subtopics.concept: Obesity risk stratification, early intervention protocols, and lifestyle modification counselling for adolescents require a structured approach to diagnosis and management. Anthropometric tools are central to identifying obesity, with BMI-for-age >95th percentile confirming obesity. Growth charts remain invaluable for tracking serial height and weight over time, as deviations from expected centile channels often precede clinical symptoms. Skinfold thickness and mid-upper arm circumference can provide additional insights into body fat and muscle mass but are less commonly used in routine adolescent practice. Dietary assessments, such as a detailed nutrient analysis of a 3-day diet record, can help estimate daily intake of calories, protein, iron, calcium, and other nutrients, which can then be compared to recommended dietary allowances. Mobile apps and software for food tracking may also assist adolescents in identifying deficiencies, such as an iron intake of only 8 mg/day against the recommended ~15 mg for adolescent girls. Laboratory investigations are essential to detect comorbidities and hidden deficiencies in obese adolescents. A fasting blood glucose, oral glucose tolerance test, or HbA1c can identify early type 2 diabetes, while a fasting lipid profile often reveals dyslipidemia, such as elevated triglycerides and low HDL. Liver function tests may show raised ALT levels, indicative of fatty liver disease. If hypertension is present, serum creatinine and urine analysis may be performed to rule out secondary causes or end-organ damage. Screening questionnaires, such as the SCOFF questionnaire, can identify eating disorders, with a score of ≥2 strongly suggesting the need for referral. The CRAFFT questionnaire is useful for screening substance use, including alcohol, which may impact nutrition. Adolescents reporting significant alcohol use should undergo liver enzyme testing and vitamin assays, such as folate and thiamine, due to alcohol’s effect on nutrient absorption. Early intervention protocols should emphasize regular growth monitoring, dietary counselling, and lifestyle modifications. Practical bedside decision-making includes identifying obesity through BMI-for-age thresholds, assessing comorbidities with targeted laboratory tests, and employing screening tools to address behavioral factors. Community programs may utilize tools like BMI wheels or reference tables for rapid classification, supporting broader obesity prevention efforts.

case_studies.title: Obesity Risk Stratification in a 14-Year-Old Girl
case_studies.vignette: A 14-year-old girl from an urban slum in Mumbai presents to the outpatient clinic with her mother, concerned about her rapid weight gain over the past year. Her mother reports sedentary habits, including prolonged screen time and frequent consumption of fried snacks and sugary drinks. The girl complains of fatigue and difficulty keeping up with physical activities at school. On examination, her BMI is 28 kg/m², placing her above the 95th percentile for her age and sex. Her blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. Growth chart review shows a sharp upward deviation in weight over the past 18 months, while height has progressed along the 50th percentile. subtopics.subtopic_title: Treatment algorithms and management protocols for moderate and severe acute malnutrition in adolescents
subtopics.concept: Treatment algorithms and management protocols for moderate and severe acute malnutrition in adolescents require a structured approach, focusing on nutritional rehabilitation and addressing underlying causes. First-line regimens involve a comprehensive clinical assessment complemented by laboratory investigations when indicated. Routine laboratory screening is not necessary for all adolescents unless nutritional status is severely compromised. However, annual anemia screening is recommended under programs like Anemia Mukt Bharat, as approximately 50% of adolescent girls aged 15–19 in India are anemic. Anemia is defined by the World Health Organization (WHO) as hemoglobin <12 g/dL for females aged 12–14 years and ≥15 years, and <13 g/dL for males ≥15 years. Severity is graded as mild (10–11.9 g/dL in nonpregnant girls), moderate (8–10.9 g/dL), and severe (<8 g/dL). A low hemoglobin result warrants further evaluation for underlying causes, such as iron deficiency, which can be confirmed by serum ferritin levels (<12 mg/L in children or <15 mg/L in adults). In practice, ferritin <30 mg/L is considered a more sensitive marker for low iron stores, or <100 mg/L in the presence of inflammation. Additional tests, including serum iron, total iron-binding capacity, and transferrin saturation (<16–20%), may support the diagnosis. For macrocytic anemia or neurologic symptoms like paresthesias or gait disturbances, vitamin B12 (<200 pg/mL) and RBC folate levels should be measured, as deficiencies are prevalent among Indian adolescents (~31% for B12 and ~37% for folate). Other investigations, such as 25-hydroxy vitamin D (<12 ng/mL), thyroid function tests, or chronic disease screens (e.g., celiac serology, HIV), may be performed based on clinical suspicion. Protocols for managing moderate-to-severe malnutrition also emphasize anthropometric indices, including BMI-for-age for thinness or overweight and height-for-age for stunting, alongside dietary and psychosocial assessments. Pediatricians should use age-specific criteria, such as WHO/IAP growth charts, to identify nutritional issues and intervene early. Monitoring involves regular follow-ups to assess growth and nutritional status, with referrals to specialized care when necessary. Adverse effects related to specific interventions were not specified in the source.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Physical activity recommendations tailored to Indian adolescents
subtopics.concept: Physical activity recommendations tailored to Indian adolescents emphasize the importance of incorporating age-appropriate exercises to promote overall health and address nutritional challenges, whether undernutrition or overweight. For undernourished adolescents, physical activity, particularly strength training such as body-weight exercises or resistance exercises under proper supervision, is encouraged as it can stimulate muscle growth and improve appetite. For overweight adolescents, a combination of aerobic exercises—such as brisk walking, cycling, or swimming—and strength training is recommended to support fat loss and enhance metabolic health. Activities that are enjoyable, such as dance, sports, or physical games, should be prioritized to ensure long-term adherence. The focus should be on finding activities that the adolescent enjoys to foster sustainability. Limiting sedentary behaviors is equally important, with recreational screen time advised to be restricted to less than two hours per day. This helps free up time for active pursuits and minimizes unhealthy habits like mindless snacking during screen use. Families can play a supportive role by organizing active outings and avoiding the use of food as the sole reward or celebration. For example, rewarding a good exam result with a trip to the park or a sports event instead of a junk food treat can reinforce positive habits. Additionally, addressing body image and eating behaviors is critical, especially for adolescents influenced by unrealistic media portrayals. It is essential to educate them about the edited and idealized nature of images on social media and promote healthy ways to achieve fitness. Building self-esteem and focusing on strengths unrelated to appearance can help reduce unhealthy weight fixations. Adolescents exhibiting extreme measures like self-induced vomiting, laxative use, or starvation require immediate intervention. These strategies aim to integrate physical activity into the daily lives of Indian adolescents while fostering a positive relationship with their bodies and overall well-being.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Nutritional management for adolescents with chronic illnesses or physical disabilities
subtopics.concept: Nutritional management for adolescents with chronic illnesses or physical disabilities requires careful consideration of eating disorders (EDs), which are prevalent in this age group and include anorexia nervosa (AN), bulimia nervosa (BN), and binge-eating disorder (BED). Pediatricians play a pivotal role in identifying these conditions early and initiating a multidisciplinary management approach focused on nutritional rehabilitation and medical stabilization, while collaborating with mental health professionals for psychotherapy. Screening during routine adolescent health visits is essential, as ED symptoms are often concealed. Clinicians should maintain a high index of suspicion and inquire about body image concerns and eating behaviors. Warning signs include dramatic weight changes, fear of weight gain, distorted body image (e.g., perceiving oneself as overweight despite being underweight), and unusual eating habits such as skipping meals, calorie obsession, or secret binge eating. Physical symptoms may include fatigue, dizziness, cold intolerance, menstrual irregularities (e.g., amenorrhea in girls with low body fat), and gastrointestinal complaints. The SCOFF questionnaire, validated in Western settings but applicable in India, is a practical screening tool for identifying EDs; two or more “yes” responses suggest possible risk. The American Academy of Pediatrics advises evaluating adolescents with weight below the 5th percentile or an unexpected weight loss of more than 10% for disordered eating. High-risk groups include athletes in weight-sensitive sports, adolescents with a family history of EDs or extreme dieting, and those with comorbid conditions like Type 1 diabetes, where insulin manipulation for weight loss may occur (“diabulimia”). When EDs are suspected, a comprehensive medical evaluation is crucial. This includes dietary recall, exercise habits, binge/purge frequency, menstrual history, mood symptoms, and a physical examination. Key assessments include weight, height, BMI, orthostatic vitals, temperature, and cardiovascular evaluation. Signs such as lanugo hair, acrocyanosis, edema, Russell’s sign, and parotid hypertrophy can aid diagnosis. Laboratory tests should evaluate complications, including anemia, leukopenia, electrolyte imbalances, and thyroid function abnormalities. Adolescents with significant bradycardia (<50 bpm), hypotension (<90/60 mmHg), or severe electrolyte disturbances may require hospital admission for safe refeeding and prevention of life-threatening complications like cardiac arrest.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Follow-up protocols and outcome evaluation metrics for adolescent nutrition interventions
subtopics.concept: Follow-up protocols and outcome evaluation metrics for adolescent nutrition interventions in the context of eating disorders (EDs) emphasize early identification, multidisciplinary management, and ongoing assessment to ensure effective treatment and recovery. Eating disorders such as anorexia nervosa (AN), bulimia nervosa (BN), and binge-eating disorder (BED) require pediatricians to play a central role in screening, nutritional rehabilitation, and medical stabilization, while collaborating with mental health professionals for psychotherapy. Screening during routine adolescent health visits is critical, as ED symptoms are often concealed. Clinicians should inquire about body image, eating behaviors, and look for red flags such as dramatic weight changes, distorted body image, unusual eating habits, fatigue, dizziness, cold intolerance, menstrual irregularities (e.g., amenorrhea in girls with AN), or unexplained gastrointestinal complaints. Practical tools like the SCOFF questionnaire, validated in Western settings but applicable in India, can help identify risk; two or more "yes" answers suggest possible ED. The American Academy of Pediatrics advises evaluating adolescents with weight below the 5th percentile or an unexpected weight drop of over 10% for disordered eating. Warning signs in overweight teens include weight cycling, parotid gland swelling, dental enamel erosion, and Russell’s sign (calluses on knuckles from induced vomiting). Importantly, BMI or illness duration alone should not determine whether treatment is offered, as adolescents with normal or above-normal BMI may still have serious EDs, including atypical anorexia or bulimia. For bedside decision-making, pediatricians should conduct a comprehensive medical evaluation when ED is suspected. This includes dietary recall, exercise habits, binge/purge frequency, menstrual history, mood symptoms, and physical exam findings such as weight, height, BMI trends, orthostatic vitals, temperature, and cardiovascular assessment. Specific signs like lanugo hair, acrocyanosis, edema, Russell’s sign, and parotid hypertrophy aid diagnosis. Laboratory tests should evaluate complications, including anemia, leukopenia, electrolyte imbalances (e.g., hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis/acidosis), elevated liver enzymes, and thyroid function abnormalities (euthyroid sick syndrome). Hospital admission is warranted for bradycardia (<50 bpm), hypotension (<90/60 mmHg), or significant electrolyte disturbances to initiate safe refeeding and prevent cardiac arrest. Outcome evaluation should monitor weight trends, cardiovascular stability, and mental health progress. Timing windows for follow-up assessments were not specified in the source.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Community-based approaches and strategies for engaging families and schools in adolescent nutrition programs
subtopics.concept: Community-based approaches to adolescent nutrition programs emphasize non-pharmacological strategies that integrate dietary counseling, physical activity promotion, and family and school engagement to address undernutrition, overweight, and unhealthy eating behaviors. Dietary modification is central to improving adolescent nutrition. For undernourished adolescents, meal plans should increase calorie and protein intake in an affordable and palatable manner. For example, a 14-year-old underweight boy may benefit from adding homemade snacks such as peanut butter sandwiches or nuts and bananas mid-morning and evening, alongside three main meals. Calorie-dense nutritious foods like ghee or oil added to dals and rice, or milk powder and nut paste in porridge, are recommended. Protein intake should be emphasized, with at least 1 gram per kilogram of body weight daily; for instance, a 40 kg underweight girl should aim for approximately 40 grams of protein from sources like pulses, legumes, eggs, milk, or meat/fish. Small, frequent meals and routine eating habits are particularly helpful for adolescents with low appetite. For overweight adolescents, dietary strategies focus on moderation and healthy substitutions rather than restrictive or fad diets, which can negatively impact growth. Reducing high-sugar and high-fat items is key, such as cutting sugary colas from two daily to none or a maximum of one per week, and replacing fast food with healthier homemade alternatives. Adolescents should be educated on reading food labels to understand calorie, sugar, and fat content, and counseled to minimize “juncs” foods (junk food, ultra-processed items, caffeinated drinks, and sugar-sweetened beverages). Energy drinks and sodas should be avoided entirely, per AAP and IAP guidelines, while water, milk, and traditional drinks like buttermilk are encouraged. Visual tools like the “plate method” (half vegetables, one-quarter protein, one-quarter grains) can help guide portion balance. Strength training under supervision can stimulate muscle growth and appetite in undernourished teens, while aerobic exercises like brisk walking, cycling, or swimming, combined with age-appropriate strength exercises, support fat loss and metabolic health in overweight adolescents. Fun activities such as sports, dance, or active games should be encouraged to ensure sustainability. Limiting recreational screen time to less than two hours per day is advised to free up time for physical activity and reduce mindless snacking. Families can promote active outings and avoid using food as the sole reward for achievements, instead opting for non-food rewards like trips to parks or sports events. Addressing body image and unhealthy eating behaviors is crucial, especially for adolescents influenced by unrealistic media portrayals. Discussions about the impact of edited social media images, promoting self-esteem, and focusing on non-appearance-related strengths can reduce fixation on weight. Adolescents engaging in extreme measures like self-induced vomiting, laxatives, or starvation require urgent intervention.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Recognition of malnutrition complications and criteria for escalating care in severe adolescent malnutrition cases
subtopics.concept: Recognition of malnutrition complications and criteria for escalating care in severe adolescent malnutrition cases require a systematic approach to admission, investigation, stabilization, and discharge planning. Admission and escalation criteria include clinical signs such as abnormal vital signs, severe dehydration, neurological symptoms, or evidence of significant bleeding. Specific thresholds for vital signs, dehydration severity, neurological compromise, or bleeding were not specified in the source. Routine laboratory screening is not necessary for every adolescent unless nutritional status is severely compromised. However, annual anemia screening is recommended under programs like Anemia Mukt Bharat, as approximately 50% of adolescent girls aged 15–19 in India are anemic. WHO defines anemia in adolescents as hemoglobin <12 g/dL for females aged 12–14 years and ≥15 years, and <13 g/dL for males ≥15 years. Severity is classified as mild (Hb 10–11.9 g/dL), moderate (Hb 8–10.9 g/dL), and severe (Hb <8 g/dL). Low hemoglobin levels warrant further testing, including serum ferritin (<12 mg/L in children, <15 mg/L in adults, or <30 mg/L for increased sensitivity, and <100 mg/L in cases of inflammation). Iron studies, such as transferrin saturation (<16–20%), may confirm iron deficiency. Macrocytic anemia or neurological symptoms like paresthesias or gait disturbances necessitate assessment of vitamin B12 (<200 pg/mL) and RBC folate levels, as deficiencies are prevalent among Indian adolescents (~31% and ~37%, respectively). Other tests, including 25-hydroxy vitamin D (<12 ng/mL for deficiency), thyroid function, and chronic disease screens (e.g., celiac serology, HIV), may be indicated based on clinical suspicion. Stabilization steps focus on nutritional rehabilitation and medical stabilization, particularly for adolescents with eating disorders like anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, or binge-eating disorder. Pediatricians should prioritize nutritional recovery while collaborating with mental health professionals for psychotherapy. Criteria for PICU admission were not specified in the source. Discharge and review triggers include identifying moderate-to-severe undernutrition or obesity, which necessitates further evaluation or referral for specialized care. Early identification using clinical criteria, such as WHO/IAP growth charts, dietary and psychosocial history, and screening for clinical deficiency signs, is critical to optimizing adolescent growth and health.

case_studies.vignette: A 16-year-old girl from a rural community in India presents to the primary health center with a 2-week history of fatigue, poor appetite, and weight loss. Her mother reports that she has had a low-grade fever for the past 5 days, which has not improved with over-the-counter medication. On examination, she appears pale and lethargic, with a BMI of 14.5 kg/m². Her vitals reveal a heart rate of 115 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg. She has mild bilateral pedal edema and dry mucous membranes. A focused abdominal exam reveals mild tenderness but no guarding or rebound. Her hemoglobin level is 7.5 g/dL, and she is noted to have a serum ferritin level of 8 ng/mL.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Algorithm for triage, admission, and discharge criteria for adolescents with severe malnutrition
subtopics.concept: The algorithm for triage, admission, and discharge criteria for adolescents with severe malnutrition involves a systematic approach to clinical assessment, laboratory investigations, stabilization, and monitoring. Admission and escalation criteria focus on vital signs, dehydration, neurological status, and bleeding. Not specified in the source are specific vital thresholds for admission or escalation. Dehydration assessment, neurological impairments, or bleeding severity are also not detailed in the source. Laboratory investigations are recommended to complement clinical assessments when indicated, but routine screening is unnecessary unless nutritional status is severely compromised. Adolescents in India are targeted for annual anemia screening under programs like Anemia Mukt Bharat, as approximately 50% of adolescent girls aged 15–19 are anemic. Hemoglobin levels should be checked if not assessed in the past year, with anemia defined by the World Health Organization (WHO) as hemoglobin <12 g/dL for 12–14-year-olds and females aged ≥15 years, and <13 g/dL for males aged ≥15 years. Severity is categorized as mild (10–11.9 g/dL for nonpregnant girls), moderate (8–10.9 g/dL), and severe (<8 g/dL). A low hemoglobin level warrants further investigation, including serum ferritin to confirm iron deficiency (<15 mg/L in adults, <12 mg/L in children, or <30 mg/L for greater sensitivity, and <100 mg/L if inflammation is present). Additional tests, such as vitamin B12 (<200 pg/mL), RBC folate, and 25-hydroxy vitamin D (<12 ng/mL), may be considered based on clinical suspicion. Thyroid function tests are indicated in obese adolescents or those with growth stunting disproportionate to nutritional status, while chronic disease screens (e.g., celiac serology, HIV) are performed as clinically indicated. Stabilization steps are not specified in the source, nor are specific thresholds for pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) admission. Discharge and review triggers are also not specified. Overall, pediatricians must systematically evaluate nutritional status during adolescent visits, incorporating anthropometric indices, dietary and psychosocial history, and clinical signs of deficiency, using age-specific criteria such as WHO/IAP growth charts. Early identification and intervention are essential to optimize adolescent growth and health.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Decision-making for outpatient vs inpatient care in adolescent malnutrition treatment failures
subtopics.concept: Decision-making for outpatient versus inpatient care in adolescent malnutrition treatment failures requires careful evaluation and a structured approach. Expected defervescence timelines are not specified in the source. Treatment failure is suspected when adolescents with eating disorders (EDs) fail to achieve medical stability or nutritional rehabilitation despite outpatient management. Warning signs include persistent bradycardia (<50 bpm), hypotension (<90/60 mmHg), electrolyte disturbances (e.g., hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis from vomiting, or metabolic acidosis from laxative abuse), or significant weight loss (e.g., weight <5th percentile or unexpected weight drop >10%). These indicators necessitate reassessment of the treatment plan and consideration for inpatient care. The stepwise work-up involves a comprehensive medical evaluation, including detailed history-taking (dietary recall, exercise habits, binge/purge frequency, menstrual history, and mood symptoms) and physical examination. Key physical findings include weight and height measurements to calculate BMI and monitor trends, orthostatic vitals to detect volume depletion, temperature (hypothermia is common in malnourished anorexia nervosa patients), and cardiovascular assessment for bradycardia or arrhythmias. Specific signs such as lanugo hair, acrocyanosis, and edema in severe anorexia, or Russell’s sign and parotid hypertrophy in bulimia, aid diagnosis. Laboratory investigations include CBC (to detect anemia or leukopenia), electrolytes (to identify disturbances like hypokalemia or metabolic derangements), liver enzymes (elevated in starvation or bingeing), and thyroid function tests (euthyroid sick syndrome in starvation). Prolonged QT on ECG is a critical concern in anorexia nervosa. Switching or extending therapy is indicated when outpatient management fails to stabilize the adolescent or prevent complications. Inpatient care is often required to initiate safe refeeding and address severe medical issues, such as cardiac arrhythmias or electrolyte imbalances, which can lead to cardiac arrest. Follow-up protocols are not specified in the source. However, ongoing monitoring of weight trends, vital signs, and laboratory parameters is essential to ensure recovery and prevent relapse. Coordination with mental health professionals for psychotherapy remains integral to long-term management.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Treatment failure and escalation strategies in adolescent malnutrition management
subtopics.concept:
MANAGEMENT – NON-PHARMACOLOGICAL STRATEGIES (OR COMMUNITY STRATEGIES)

Non-pharmacological interventions are the backbone of improving adolescent nutrition,  both at
the individual level in clinical practice and at the community level. the primary  strategy is
dietary counseling and modification. for an undernourished adolescent, this  means creating a
meal plan that increases calorie and protein intake in a palatable,  affordable way. for
example, if a 14-year-old boy is underweight, one might advise adding an  extra homemade snack
mid-morning and evening (like a peanut butter sandwich or a  handful of nuts and a banana) in
addition to three main meals. encourage inclusion of  calorie-dense nutritious foods – adding a
spoon of ghee or oil to dals and rice, using milk  powder or nut paste to enrich porridge, etc.
protein should come from available sources:  pulses and legumes (dal, chickpeas, soy) are vital
for vegetarians, while eggs, milk, and some  meat/fish (if non-veg) provide high-quality
protein. emphasize at least 1 gram of protein per  kg body weight per day in these teens; for
instance, an underweight 40 kg girl should aim  ~40 g protein daily from these foods. small,
frequent meals can help those with low  appetite, and making eating a routine (don’t skip
meals) is stressed.  For overweight adolescents, dietary strategy focuses on healthy
substitutions and  moderation. they should not be put on fad or very restrictive diets, as that
can backfire or  affect growth. instead, guide them to reduce intake of high-sugar and high-fat
items: for  instance, if a teenager currently drinks two sugary colas a day, a realistic goal
is to cut down  to none or a maximum of one per week, replacing with water, coconut water or
unsweetened lemonade. if fast food consumption is thrice a week, reduce it to once a week  as a
treat, and find healthier homemade alternatives on other days. teaching them to read  food
labels for calorie, sugar, and fat content can be empowering – many are surprised that  a pack

subtopics.subtopic_title: Nutritional management for adolescents with psychosocial challenges
subtopics.concept: Nutritional management for adolescents with psychosocial challenges requires a comprehensive and integrated approach, particularly in the context of eating disorders (EDs), which include anorexia nervosa (AN), bulimia nervosa (BN), and binge-eating disorder (BED). Pediatricians play a pivotal role in identifying and managing these conditions, as they lie at the intersection of nutrition and mental health. Early recognition is critical, as adolescents with EDs often conceal their symptoms. Routine screening during adolescent health visits should include questions about body image and eating behaviors. Red flags for EDs include dramatic weight loss or fluctuations, intense fear of weight gain, distorted body image (e.g., an underweight adolescent perceiving themselves as “fat”), and unusual eating habits such as skipping meals, excessive focus on calorie counting, or secret binge eating. Subtle physical signs, such as fatigue, dizziness, cold intolerance, and menstrual irregularities (e.g., amenorrhea in anorexia nervosa), may also indicate underlying EDs. For bedside decision-making, pediatricians should prioritize nutritional rehabilitation and medical stabilization as initial management steps, while coordinating care with mental health professionals for psychotherapy. Nutritional rehabilitation focuses on restoring adequate caloric intake and correcting deficiencies to support physical and psychological recovery. Laboratory investigations complement clinical assessment when indicated but are not routinely necessary for all adolescents unless nutritional status is significantly compromised. Screening for anemia is essential, particularly in India, where programs like Anemia Mukt Bharat target annual testing for adolescents. Hemoglobin thresholds for anemia are defined by WHO as <12 g/dL for 12–14-year-olds and females aged ≥15 years, and <13 g/dL for males aged ≥15 years, with severity graded as mild (10–11.9 g/dL), moderate (8–10.9 g/dL), and severe (<8 g/dL). Iron deficiency, confirmed by low serum ferritin (<12 mg/L in children, <15 mg/L in adults, or <30 mg/L for greater sensitivity), is the most common cause. Additional tests, such as vitamin B12, folate, or vitamin D levels, may be warranted based on clinical suspicion. Early identification and intervention for EDs and nutritional deficiencies are crucial to optimizing adolescent growth, health, and psychosocial well-being.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Programmatic approaches to scaling adolescent nutrition interventions in India
subtopics.concept: Programmatic approaches to scaling adolescent nutrition interventions in India must address the complex interplay between eating disorders (EDs) and nutrition in adolescents, with a focus on early identification and multidisciplinary management. Eating disorders such as anorexia nervosa (AN), bulimia nervosa (BN), and binge-eating disorder (BED) often remain concealed, necessitating a high index of suspicion among pediatricians during routine adolescent health visits. Screening questions about body image and eating behaviors should be integrated into these visits, as adolescents may present with red flags such as dramatic weight changes, fear of weight gain, distorted body image, or unusual eating habits (e.g., skipping meals, calorie obsession, or secret binge eating). Physical signs like fatigue, dizziness, cold intolerance, menstrual irregularities in girls (e.g., amenorrhea in anorexia due to low body fat), or unexplained gastrointestinal complaints may also be subtle indicators of EDs. The SCOFF questionnaire, validated in Western settings but applicable in India, serves as a practical screening tool, with two or more “yes” responses suggesting possible ED. The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends evaluating adolescents with weight below the 5th percentile or an unexpected weight drop of over 10% for disordered eating. Overweight adolescents should be assessed for bulimia or BED if warning signs such as weight cycling, parotid gland swelling, dental enamel erosion, or calluses on knuckles (Russell’s sign) are present. Importantly, a normal or above-normal BMI does not exclude the possibility of serious EDs, as bulimia and atypical anorexia may occur in adolescents with seemingly healthy weights. Pediatricians should avoid relying solely on BMI or illness duration to determine treatment eligibility, as emphasized by NICE guidelines. High-risk groups, including athletes in weight-sensitive sports, adolescents with a family history of EDs, extreme dieting, or comorbid conditions like Type 1 diabetes (e.g., diabulimia), require targeted screening. Early conversations about body image and eating behaviors, along with parental input, can facilitate timely identification and referral. Comprehensive medical evaluations, including dietary recall, physical exams, and laboratory tests, are essential for assessing complications and initiating nutritional stabilization. Hospital admission may be warranted for adolescents with significant bradycardia (<50 bpm), hypotension (<90/60 mmHg), or electrolyte disturbances to ensure safe refeeding and prevent cardiac complications.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Monitoring and evaluation frameworks for adolescent nutrition programs
subtopics.concept: Monitoring and evaluation frameworks for adolescent nutrition programs must incorporate strategies to address eating disorders (EDs) such as anorexia nervosa (AN), bulimia nervosa (BN), and binge-eating disorder (BED). Early identification and intervention are crucial, as these disorders lie at the intersection of nutrition and mental health. Pediatricians play a central role in screening for EDs during routine adolescent health visits and initiating management focused on nutritional rehabilitation and medical stabilization, while coordinating care with mental health professionals for psychotherapy. Adolescents with EDs often conceal their symptoms, necessitating a high index of suspicion during clinical evaluations. Routine screening questions about body image and eating behaviors should be integrated into adolescent visits, with attention to red flags such as dramatic weight loss or fluctuations, intense fear of weight gain, distorted body image, skipping meals, hyper-focusing on calories, secret binge eating, fatigue, dizziness, cold intolerance, menstrual irregularities (e.g., amenorrhea in anorexia due to low body fat), or unexplained gastrointestinal complaints. The SCOFF questionnaire, a practical screening tool consisting of five yes/no questions about eating attitudes, is useful for quickly assessing risk, with ≥2 "yes" responses suggesting possible ED. Despite being validated in Western settings, it can be applied in India. According to the American Academy of Pediatrics, adolescents with weight <5th percentile or an unexpected weight drop of >10% should be evaluated for disordered eating. Pediatricians should also be vigilant for signs of bulimia or BED in overweight teens, including weight cycling, parotid gland swelling, dental enamel erosion, and calluses on knuckles (Russell’s sign). Importantly, an adolescent need not be underweight to have a serious ED, as many with bulimia or atypical anorexia may have normal or above-normal BMI but still engage in harmful behaviors. NICE guidelines emphasize that single measures such as BMI or illness duration should not determine treatment eligibility. High-risk groups, such as athletes in weight-sensitive sports, adolescents with a family history of EDs, extreme dieting, or comorbid conditions like Type 1 diabetes (e.g., diabulimia), warrant proactive screening. Early conversations about body image and eating behaviors during clinic visits, coupled with input from parents, can prompt timely referrals. Medical assessment and nutritional stabilization are essential when an ED is suspected. A comprehensive history should include dietary recall, exercise habits, binge/purge frequency, menstrual history, and mood symptoms. Physical examination should focus on weight, height, BMI, orthostatic vitals (tachycardia, hypotension, or dizziness suggest volume depletion in AN), temperature (hypothermia is common in malnourished AN patients), and cardiovascular assessment (bradycardia, arrhythmias, or prolonged QT on ECG in AN). Diagnostic signs such as lanugo hair, acrocyanosis, and edema in severe anorexia, or Russell’s sign and parotid hypertrophy in bulimia, aid diagnosis. Laboratory tests should evaluate complications, including anemia or leukopenia (marrow suppression in AN), electrolyte disturbances (e.g., hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis from vomiting, or metabolic acidosis from laxative abuse), elevated liver enzymes (starvation or bingeing), and thyroid dysfunction (euthyroid sick syndrome). Hospital admission is warranted for significant bradycardia (<50 bpm), hypotension (<90/60 mmHg), or electrolyte disturbances to safely initiate refeeding and prevent cardiac arrest.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Integration of adolescent nutrition into school health initiatives
subtopics.concept: Integration of adolescent nutrition into school health initiatives is crucial for promoting healthy growth and development during this critical period. Non-pharmacological strategies form the backbone of improving adolescent nutrition, focusing on dietary counseling, modification, and lifestyle changes. For undernourished adolescents, meal plans should aim to increase calorie and protein intake in a palatable and affordable manner. For instance, a 14-year-old boy who is underweight may benefit from adding extra homemade snacks, such as a peanut butter sandwich or a handful of nuts and a banana, mid-morning and evening, alongside three main meals. Calorie-dense nutritious foods, such as ghee or oil added to dals and rice, or milk powder and nut paste to enrich porridge, should be encouraged. Protein intake should be tailored to at least 1 gram per kilogram of body weight per day; for example, an underweight 40 kg girl should aim for approximately 40 grams of protein daily from sources like pulses, legumes, eggs, milk, and meat or fish (if non-vegetarian). Small, frequent meals and establishing a routine to avoid skipping meals are practical strategies for adolescents with low appetite. For overweight adolescents, the focus should shift to healthy substitutions and moderation rather than restrictive diets, which can negatively impact growth. Reducing high-sugar and high-fat items is essential; for example, cutting down sugary colas from two per day to none or a maximum of one per week, replacing them with water, coconut water, or unsweetened lemonade. Fast food consumption can be reduced from thrice a week to once, with healthier homemade alternatives on other days. Teaching adolescents to read food labels for calorie, sugar, and fat content can empower them to make informed choices. The concept of “juncs” foods (junk food, ultra-processed items, nutritionally inappropriate foods, caffeinated drinks, and sugar-sweetened beverages) should be emphasized, with energy drinks and sodas strictly avoided. Instead, water, milk, or traditional drinks like buttermilk should be encouraged. The “plate method” is a useful visual guide for portion balance, with half the plate dedicated to vegetables, a quarter to protein, and a quarter to grains. Thin adolescents may benefit from strength training exercises to stimulate muscle growth and appetite, while overweight teens should engage in a mix of aerobic exercises (e.g., brisk walking, cycling, swimming) and age-appropriate strength training to improve fat loss and metabolic health. Fun activities like dance, sports, or physical games can make exercise sustainable, with the key being to find activities they enjoy. subtopics.subtopic_title: Best practices for adolescent nutrition education in community settings
subtopics.concept: Best practices for adolescent nutrition education in community settings emphasize non-pharmacological strategies as the cornerstone for improving nutritional health. Dietary counseling and modification are central to addressing both undernutrition and overweight issues. For undernourished adolescents, meal plans should focus on increasing calorie and protein intake in a palatable and affordable manner. For example, a 14-year-old boy who is underweight can be advised to include an extra homemade snack, such as a peanut butter sandwich or a handful of nuts and a banana, mid-morning and evening, in addition to three main meals. Incorporating calorie-dense nutritious foods, such as adding ghee or oil to dals and rice or enriching porridge with milk powder or nut paste, is recommended. Protein intake should be emphasized, with a target of at least 1 gram per kilogram of body weight daily. For instance, a 40 kg underweight girl should aim for approximately 40 grams of protein per day, sourced from pulses, legumes, eggs, milk, or meat/fish, depending on dietary preferences. Small, frequent meals and establishing a routine to avoid skipping meals can be helpful for adolescents with low appetite. For overweight adolescents, the focus should be on healthy substitutions and moderation rather than restrictive or fad diets, which may negatively impact growth and development. Reducing high-sugar and high-fat items is essential, such as cutting down sugary colas from two per day to none or one per week and replacing them with water, coconut water, or unsweetened lemonade. Fast food consumption can be reduced from thrice a week to once a week, with healthier homemade alternatives suggested for other days. Teaching adolescents to read food labels for calorie, sugar, and fat content can empower them to make informed choices. In India, the concept of “juncs” foods—junk food, ultra-processed, nutritionally inappropriate items, caffeinated drinks, and sugar-sweetened beverages—has been promoted, and adolescents should limit these to an absolute minimum. Energy drinks and sodas, as per AAP and IAP guidelines, should be avoided entirely. Instead, water, milk, and traditional drinks like buttermilk should be encouraged, alongside meals rich in salads, fruits, whole grains, and foods prepared using healthier methods like grilling or steaming. The “plate method,” which visually divides a plate into half vegetables, a quarter protein, and a quarter grains, is a practical tool for portion balance. For undernourished teens, strength training exercises, such as body-weight or resistance exercises under proper guidance, can stimulate muscle growth and appetite. For overweight adolescents, a combination of aerobic exercises, such as brisk walking, cycling, or swimming, and age-appropriate strength training can promote fat loss and improve metabolic health. Fun activities like dance, sports, or physical games should be encouraged to ensure sustainability, with a focus on activities the adolescent enjoys. Sedentary time, including recreational screen time, should be limited to less than two hours per day to free up time for active pursuits and reduce unhealthy behaviors like mindless snacking during screen use. Families can be encouraged to plan active outings and use non-food rewards for celebrations, such as a trip to the park or a sports event instead of junk food treats. Finally, addressing body image and eating behaviors is crucial, particularly for adolescent girls who may experience body dissatisfaction. Discussions about the unrealistic nature of edited images on social media and promoting healthy ways to achieve fitness are important. Building self-esteem by focusing on non-appearance-related strengths can help reduce an unhealthy fixation on weight. If extreme measures, such as self-induced vomiting, laxative use, or starvation, are identified, further intervention is warranted.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Psychosocial support integration in adolescent nutrition programs
subtopics.concept: Psychosocial support integration in adolescent nutrition programs is critical for addressing the intersection of nutritional health and mental well-being, particularly in the context of eating disorders (EDs). Eating disorders, including anorexia nervosa (AN), bulimia nervosa (BN), and binge-eating disorder (BED), are prevalent among adolescents and require early identification and a multidisciplinary management strategy. Pediatricians play a central role in screening for EDs during routine visits, focusing on nutritional rehabilitation and medical stabilization while coordinating care with mental health professionals for psychotherapy. Since eating disorders often involve concealed symptoms, clinicians must maintain a high index of suspicion and incorporate routine screening questions about body image and eating behaviors into adolescent health evaluations. Red flags for EDs include dramatic weight loss or fluctuation, intense fear of weight gain, distorted body image (such as perceiving oneself as overweight despite being underweight), and unusual eating habits like skipping meals, hyper-focusing on calorie intake, or secret binge eating. Early physical signs may be subtle, such as fatigue, dizziness, cold intolerance, and menstrual irregularities in girls, with amenorrhea being common in cases of anorexia nervosa. From a practical standpoint, integrating psychosocial support into adolescent nutrition programs involves creating a safe and nonjudgmental environment for adolescents to discuss their eating behaviors and body image concerns. Pediatricians should work collaboratively with dietitians, psychologists, and other healthcare professionals to ensure a holistic approach to care. Nutritional rehabilitation should be tailored to the individual needs of the adolescent, addressing both physical and psychological aspects of recovery. Psychotherapy, including cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), is often necessary to address underlying emotional and psychological factors contributing to EDs. Routine follow-up visits should monitor progress in both nutritional status and mental health, ensuring that interventions are effective and adjusted as needed. By integrating psychosocial support into nutrition programs, pediatricians can play a pivotal role in optimizing adolescent health and preventing long-term complications associated with eating disorders.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Comprehensive nutritional assessment and anthropometric tools for Indian adolescents
subtopics.concept: A comprehensive nutritional assessment is essential in paediatric practice to identify malnutrition early, particularly among Indian adolescents. Anthropometry forms the cornerstone of this assessment, focusing on physical growth parameters and comparing them to standard growth charts. Key indicators include weight-for-age (to screen for underweight), length/height-for-age (to detect stunting or chronic malnutrition), and weight-for-height or BMI-for-age (to identify wasting, acute malnutrition, or overweight). These indices are interpreted using z-scores or percentiles derived from reference populations, such as WHO Child Growth Standards for ages 0–5 years and Indian Academy of Pediatrics (IAP) growth references for older children. Malnutrition severity is classified based on z-score deviations from the median: moderate malnutrition is indicated by a z-score below –2, while severe malnutrition is below –3. For example, weight-for-length < –3 z-scores indicates severe acute malnutrition (SAM), and between –2 and –3 z-scores indicates moderate acute malnutrition (MAM). Similarly, stunting is defined as height-for-age < –2 z-scores (moderate) or < –3 z-scores (severe). Practical bedside tools include routine measurements of weight, length/height, and mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC). Infants and young children should be weighed using infant or electronic scales (to the nearest 100 g), with length measured lying down on an infantometer (<2 years) or height standing with a stadiometer (≥2 years) to the nearest 0.1 cm. Head circumference is measured in infants up to 1–2 years to monitor brain growth and nutritional status. MUAC, measured at the midpoint of the left arm between the shoulder and elbow, is a rapid community screening tool for acute malnutrition, especially in health camps or by ASHA workers. A MUAC <115 mm (<11.5 cm) identifies SAM in children aged 6–59 months, while 115–125 mm indicates moderate malnutrition. Color-banded MUAC tapes simplify interpretation, with red zones denoting severe malnutrition. For adolescents over 5 years, BMI-for-age is calculated using weight and height, plotted on age- and sex-specific charts. A BMI below the 5th percentile suggests undernutrition, while values above the 85th or 95th percentile indicate overweight risk. Frequent growth monitoring is critical. The IAP recommends monthly growth checks in the first year, every two months in the second year, and every three months from ages 2–5 years. Government ICDS guidelines align, advising monthly weighing for children under 3 years and quarterly for those aged 3–5 years, with weight plotted on the Mother and Child Protection (MCP) card. At each paediatric visit, measuring weight and length/height is crucial for continuous screening. While a single measurement classifies current status, tracking growth trends over time is more informative. Flattening or declining growth curves across percentiles signals early malnutrition. For example, if a child’s weight-for-age percentile drops from the 50th at birth to the 10th by nine months, even without a z-score indicating underweight, feeding practices and illness must be assessed. Growth charts, often color-coded, facilitate visualization of growth velocity, helping identify faltering early. However, normal variability must be considered; a child consistently tracking the 5th percentile may simply be constitutionally small, whereas crossing percentiles downward is concerning. Combined information from these tools aids in early intervention.

case_studies.title: Cultural Influences on Adolescent Eating Behaviors in India
case_studies.vignette: A 15-year-old girl from a semi-urban Indian setting presents to the pediatric clinic with complaints of persistent fatigue, dizziness, and cold intolerance over the past 3 months. Her mother reports that she has been increasingly avoiding family meals, citing a desire to 'eat healthy' and lose weight. The girl has recently stopped eating traditional foods like rice and chapati, instead consuming only fruits and salads. She has lost 6 kg in the past 2 months and has become more withdrawn socially. On examination, she is pale, her BMI is 16 (low for age), and her vitals show a heart rate of 58 bpm and BP of 90/60 mmHg. Menstrual history reveals amenorrhea for the past 3 months. When asked about her eating habits, she hesitates but admits to skipping meals and feeling guilty after eating more than planned.

subtopics.concept: Community and school-based strategies play a pivotal role in improving adolescent nutrition, focusing on dietary counseling, modification, and physical activity promotion. For undernourished adolescents, the primary goal is to increase calorie and protein intake in a palatable and affordable manner. Practical recommendations include adding extra homemade snacks, such as a peanut butter sandwich or a handful of nuts and a banana, mid-morning and evening, alongside three main meals. Calorie-dense nutritious foods, such as ghee or oil added to dals and rice, and milk powder or nut paste enriched porridge, should be encouraged. Protein intake should be prioritized, with a target of at least 1 gram per kilogram of body weight daily. For example, an underweight 40 kg adolescent girl should aim for approximately 40 grams of protein per day from sources like pulses, legumes, eggs, milk, and meat or fish (if non-vegetarian). Small, frequent meals and establishing a routine to avoid skipping meals can benefit adolescents with low appetite. For overweight adolescents, dietary strategies emphasize healthy substitutions and moderation rather than restrictive or fad diets, which may negatively impact growth. Reducing high-sugar and high-fat items is key, such as cutting down sugary colas from two per day to none or a maximum of one per week, replacing them with water, coconut water, or unsweetened lemonade. Fast food consumption should be limited, for instance, reducing intake from three times a week to once as a treat, while opting for healthier homemade alternatives. Adolescents can be taught to read food labels to understand calorie, sugar, and fat content, empowering them to make informed choices. In India, the concept of “juncs” foods—junk food, ultra-processed items, sugar-sweetened beverages, and caffeinated drinks—is promoted, with adolescents counseled to minimize their consumption. Energy drinks and sodas should be avoided as routine beverages, as per AAP and IAP guidelines. Instead, water, milk, or traditional drinks like buttermilk should be encouraged. The “plate method,” which visually divides a plate into half vegetables, a quarter protein, and a quarter grains, can guide portion balance effectively. Strength training under proper guidance can stimulate muscle growth and appetite in thin adolescents, while a mix of aerobic and age-appropriate strength exercises can promote fat loss and metabolic health in overweight teens. Fun activities like dance, sports, or physical games should be encouraged to ensure sustainability. Recreational screen time should be limited to less than two hours per day to free up time for active pursuits and reduce mindless snacking. Families can foster active outings and avoid using food as the sole reward or celebration. Addressing body image issues is essential, as many adolescents may develop unhealthy behaviors due to dissatisfaction with their appearance. Discussions about media influence, unrealistic social media images, and healthy ways to achieve fitness, along with building self-esteem and focusing on non-appearance-related strengths, can help reduce fixation on weight. case_studies.title: Persistent Fatigue in a 14-Year-Old Girl: A Community Nutrition Perspective
case_studies.vignette: A 14-year-old girl from a rural Indian village presents to the community health center with complaints of persistent fatigue, difficulty concentrating in school, and occasional dizziness for the past month. Her mother reports she has been skipping breakfast and often eats only rice with minimal vegetables for lunch and dinner. She is reluctant to eat mid-morning snacks provided at school, citing taste preferences. On examination, she appears pale and has a BMI of 15.5 kg/m² (underweight). Her vitals are stable, with a heart rate of 88 bpm and blood pressure of 100/70 mmHg. A hemoglobin test reveals a level of 9.2 g/dL. The school recently initiated a midday meal program, but the girl has not been consistently participating. The community health worker discusses the barriers to her participation and explores strategies to improve her nutrition intake.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Scaling and sustaining adolescent nutrition interventions in India
subtopics.concept: The scaling and sustaining of adolescent nutrition interventions in India must address the critical issue of eating disorders (EDs) among adolescents, including anorexia nervosa (AN), bulimia nervosa (BN), and binge-eating disorder (BED). Early identification and multidisciplinary management are essential, with pediatricians playing a pivotal role in screening for EDs during routine visits and initiating nutritional rehabilitation and medical stabilization while coordinating psychotherapy with mental health professionals. Eating disorders lie at the intersection of nutrition and mental health, necessitating an integrated approach. Adolescents with EDs often conceal symptoms, making routine screening for body image concerns and eating behaviors vital during health visits. Red flags include dramatic weight loss or fluctuations, intense fear of weight gain, distorted body image (e.g., perceiving oneself as "fat" despite being underweight), and unusual eating habits such as skipping meals or secret binge eating. Physical signs may be subtle initially, such as fatigue, dizziness, cold intolerance, amenorrhea in girls (linked to low body fat in AN), or unexplained gastrointestinal complaints. The SCOFF questionnaire, validated in Western settings but applicable in India, is a practical screening tool, with ≥2 “yes” answers indicating possible ED risk. The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends evaluation for disordered eating in adolescents with weight <5th percentile or unexpected weight loss >10%. Overweight adolescents may show signs of bulimia or BED, such as weight cycling, parotid gland swelling, dental enamel erosion, and calluses on knuckles (Russell’s sign). Importantly, adolescents with normal or above-normal BMI can still have serious EDs, as emphasized by NICE guidelines, which caution against using single measures like BMI or illness duration to determine treatment eligibility. High-risk groups, including athletes in weight-sensitive sports, those with a family history of EDs, extreme dieting, or comorbid conditions like Type 1 diabetes (e.g., "diabulimia"), require targeted screening. Early discussions about body image and eating behaviors during clinic visits, along with parental input, can facilitate timely intervention. Comprehensive medical evaluation, including dietary recall, physical exam, and lab tests, is essential for diagnosis and stabilization. Severe cases with bradycardia (<50 bpm), hypotension (<90/60 mmHg), or electrolyte disturbances may require hospital admission to safely initiate refeeding and prevent complications such as cardiac arrest.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Recognition of eating disorder complications and escalation of care
subtopics.concept:
PREVENTION – LEVELS OF PREVENTION

Given the long-term implications of adolescent nutrition, preventive strategies are  paramount
and are often conceptualized at three levels: primary, secondary, and tertiary  prevention. Primary prevention aims to avert nutritional problems before they develop by promoting  healthy
behaviors and environments among all adolescents. this includes ensuring food  security and
access to a balanced diet in the population (for instance, strengthening public  distribution
systems so that families with adolescents can obtain sufficient grains, pulses,  etc.), and
nutrition education from an early age. one primary preventive measure in india is  universal
fortification of staples – iodized salt to prevent iodine deficiency (which indirectly
prevents cognitive deficits in adolescents), and newer policies like iron-fortified rice in
government feeding programs to reduce anemia. vaccinations and infection control also play  a
role in primary prevention by reducing disease-related malnutrition; for example,  deworming
prophylactically every 6 months prevents helminth-induced malnutrition in  endemic regions. health education campaigns encouraging adolescents to eat home-cooked  meals, plenty of
fruits/vegetables, and to limit junk food and sugary drinks are primary  prevention to combat
both under- and overnutrition. for example, the slogan “eat right and  play hard” targeting
schoolchildren to develop a habit of balanced diet and daily exercise is a  primary prevention
message to stave off later obesity and diabetes. another primary  prevention strategy is life-
skills training in schools – teaching young adolescents skills like  gardening, cooking simple
healthy recipes, or reading nutrition labels fosters long-term  healthy habits. Secondary
prevention involves early detection and prompt intervention to halt progression  of a
nutritional problem that has begun. screening programs are quintessential secondary
prevention. for instance, conducting annual anemia screening camps in schools for  adolescent
girls, and providing iron supplements to those found anemic, is secondary  prevention to stop

(BN),  AND binge-EATING disorder (BED) – require early identification AND a multidisciplinary
MANAGEMENT strategy. Pediatricians play a key role IN SCREENING FOR EDs during routine visits
AND providing initial MANAGEMENT focused on NUTRITIONAL rehabilitation AND medical stability,
while coordinating with mental health professionals FOR psychotherapy. From a CLINICAL
perspective, EATING DISORDERS lie at the intersection OF NUTRITION AND mental health, so AN
integrated APPROACH is essential.  SCREENING AND Early Recognition: ADOLESCENTS with EATING
DISORDERS often conceal their  symptoms, so clinicians must maintain a high index OF suspicion.
Routine SCREENING questions  about BODY IMAGE AND EATING behaviors should be part OF ADOLESCENT
health visits. Red flags  include dramatic weight loss or fluctuation, intense fear OF weight
gain, a distorted BODY IMAGE  (e.g. a teen WHO is underweight but perceives themselves as
